case_vignette: A 35-year-old woman presents to an outpatient clinic during winter for persistant rhinorrhea. She states it is persistent and seems to be worse when she goes outside. Otherwise, she states she is generally healthy and only has a history of constipation. Her temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 144/91 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Nasal sputum cytology reveals eosinophilia and boggy turbinates.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. No, I haven't been taking any medications.

No, my family members haven't had similar symptoms.

No, I haven't been to any new places or traveled recently.

No, I haven't been exposed to any animals or pets recently.

No, I haven't been experiencing any stress or anxiety.

Yes, I've been getting enough sleep and eating a healthy diet.
Have you been experiencing any other symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, or joint pain?
No, I haven't experienced any other symptoms like headaches, fatigue, or joint pain.
Final Diagnosis: Rhinitis.
